elements.title: Gift-First Information Hierarchy: Value Before Form Fields
elements.problem: The current platform information hierarchy leads with what it needs from the host (forms, fields, inputs) rather than what it gives. Cialdini's reciprocity research establishes that compliance follows gifts, not requests. Bryant's call with Sherene demonstrates ideal information hierarchy: he opens every topic with what Split Lease provides (cleaning management, separate sheets, photo documentation, lockbox, daily payment) and only then surfaces what Sherene needs to provide (availability, price floor, house rules). The platform inverts this: landing on any creation or response page, the host sees input fields first and value statements second (or not at all). This ordering violates the reciprocity principle -- the host must perceive receiving before being asked to give.
elements.solution: Restructure information hierarchy across all host-facing pages to follow the gift-first pattern: (1) Primary position (top of viewport, first scan point): what the platform is giving the host right now. For onboarding: 'Based on your conversation with Bryant, here is what we already know about your listing.' For proposal response: 'Here is what Greg and Johan are offering you.' For listing creation: 'Your estimated monthly earnings: $1,200+.' (2) Secondary position: context that reinforces the gift. For onboarding: pre-filled fields showing information already captured. For proposals: guest profiles with vetting results. (3) Tertiary position: what the host needs to provide. This comes LAST, after the host has received value. (4) The visual weight must match the hierarchy: gifts should be large, bold, and prominent. Forms should be lighter, less visually demanding, positioned below the fold if possible.

evidence.quote: Bryant spends the first 4+ minutes of the call giving Sherene information: the ghost roommate model, guest schedules, cleaning protocol, separate sheets solution, and a price concession. Sherene's first request (asking about laundry at 02:03) comes only AFTER she has received substantial value. Her concerns emerge naturally from the information Bryant gave, not from questions he asked.
evidence.insight: In the call, information flows gift-first: Bryant gives, Sherene responds. Forms on the platform reverse this flow: the platform asks, the host must provide. The information architecture must replicate the call's gift-first hierarchy.

evidence.quote: Just tell her you would like her to try the products... That's an offer no one can refuse. At the end of the trial period, the Amway representative returns and picks up orders for those of the products the customer wishes to purchase.
evidence.insight: The BUG puts products in the customer's hands (gift first) and THEN requests orders. The information equivalent: put value in the host's eyes (earnings estimate, guest profiles, pre-filled data) and THEN request inputs. The information hierarchy IS the reciprocity mechanism in digital form.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: what the platform gives (earnings, guest profiles, pre-filled data). Secondary: context reinforcing the gift (how the arrangement works, what's included). Tertiary: what the host needs to provide (form fields, confirmations, decisions). The ratio should be approximately 60% gift information to 40% request information on any given screen.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive gift disclosure: reveal one gift at a time, with each gift creating enough obligation for the host to reciprocate with one small action. Do not reveal all gifts at once (this converts a cascade into a dump). Do not ask for actions before the corresponding gift has been received and cognitively processed (minimum 2-second gap between gift display and action request).
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 gift items visible simultaneously (to prevent overwhelm). Maximum 3 form fields visible at once (to prevent form fatigue). Each gift item should be expressible in under 15 words. Each form field should have a visible label explaining why this data matters to the host's outcome (not why it matters to the platform).
scan_order: Gift headline: what you are receiving right now (e.g., 'Your estimated earnings: $1,200/month')
Gift evidence: supporting detail that makes the gift concrete (e.g., '2 guests, 6 nights/week, $40/night average')
Action request: what we need from you to continue (e.g., 'Confirm your room availability dates')
exclude: Platform-centric language ('We need', 'Please provide', 'Required fields') in primary or secondary positions. This language belongs in tertiary position only.
Legal disclaimers or terms-of-service links in the primary scan path. These block the gift-first pattern.
Feature lists that describe what the platform CAN do without tying each feature to a specific benefit for THIS host in THIS arrangement.

elements.title: Concern-Solution Pairing: Mirror the Call's Reciprocal Dialogue Structure
elements.problem: Bryant's call with Sherene follows a natural reciprocal dialogue: Sherene raises a concern, Bryant immediately provides a solution, the concern resolves, and a new one emerges. This back-and-forth structure is the information architecture of trust-building through reciprocity. But the platform does not replicate this structure. FAQ pages list answers without concerns. Feature pages list capabilities without problems. Listing creation pages present fields without explaining what anxiety each field resolves. The information is organized by platform categories (features, pricing, rules) rather than by host concerns (cleaning, security, strangers, money). This means the host must do the cognitive work of mapping platform categories to their own concerns -- a translation effort that Bryant handles effortlessly in conversation.
elements.solution: Restructure host-facing information into concern-solution pairs that mirror the call's dialogue structure. (1) During evaluation: present information as a series of cards, each starting with a common host concern ('Worried about cleaning between guests?') followed immediately by the platform's solution ('Ghost roommates manage cleaning with a shared checklist. Here is how it works.'). This mirrors Bryant at 01:14-01:45. (2) During onboarding: instead of a generic welcome, show a personalized concern-solution feed based on topics from the host's call. For Sherene: 'You asked about laundry -- here is how it works. You asked about security -- here is what's in place.' (3) During listing creation: label each wizard step with the concern it resolves. Step 5 (Rules) becomes 'Protect Your Space: Set expectations guests must follow.' Step 6 (Photos) becomes 'Build Guest Confidence: Show them what to expect.' (4) Each concern-solution pair should end with a micro-confirmation from the platform: 'Got it. Your cleaning preferences are saved.' This mirrors Bryant's conversational acknowledgments ('I can let you know', 'I'll confirm that').

evidence.quote: Cleaning concern (02:51) -> Bryant: guest-managed cleaning with checklists (01:14). Laundry concern (02:03) -> Bryant: separate sheets + laundromat option (03:03-03:30). Price concern (04:32) -> Bryant: price above $1000 (04:15). Security concern (17:42) -> Bryant: security deposit (17:42-18:06). Key management concern (17:08) -> Bryant: electronic lockbox (17:08-17:23). Each concern is resolved in under 60 seconds.
evidence.insight: The call's information architecture is concern-resolution-concern-resolution. The platform must replicate this rhythm. Presenting all solutions at once without their corresponding concerns removes the reciprocal dynamic -- the host doesn't feel their specific anxiety was heard and addressed.

evidence.quote: The reciprocation rule brings about mutual concession in two ways. The first is obvious. It pressures the recipient of an already-made concession to respond in kind.
evidence.insight: Each concern-solution pair is a micro-concession from the platform: the host voices a concern (a form of vulnerability), and the platform responds with a solution (a concession/gift). This micro-concession pattern pressures the host to reciprocate with continued engagement and, ultimately, commitment.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the host's concern stated in their language. Secondary: the platform's solution, specific and concrete. Tertiary: proof/evidence that the solution works (e.g., 'Used by 85% of ghost roommate hosts'). The concern must ALWAYS appear before the solution in the reading order -- solution before concern breaks the reciprocal dialogue structure.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Sequential concern-solution disclosure: reveal one pair at a time, with a 'continue' or natural scroll action between pairs. Do not dump all concern-solution pairs simultaneously. The pacing should mirror conversational rhythm: one topic every 30-60 seconds of reading time, matching the cadence of the Sherene-Bryant call.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 concern-solution pair per viewport on mobile. Maximum 2 on desktop. Each concern should be stated in under 10 words. Each solution should be stated in under 30 words, with optional expansion for detail.
scan_order: Concern label: phrased as the host would say it ('What about cleaning between guests?')
Solution summary: one sentence ('Guests manage cleaning with a shared checklist you approve.')
Solution detail (expandable): how it works in practice
Micro-confirmation: 'This is included in your arrangement at no extra cost.'
exclude: Solutions without their corresponding concerns. A feature like 'electronic lockbox' means nothing without the concern it addresses ('How do guests get keys without me being home?').
Concerns that are not relevant to this host's specific situation. Sherene asked about vaccination and cleaning -- a host with a single long-term guest may not have these concerns.
Jargon that the host would not use. 'Secure access provisioning' instead of 'electronic lockbox.' Use the host's vocabulary, not the platform's.

elements.title: Guest Profile as Stranger-to-Person Disclosure Sequence
elements.problem: Sherene's core anxiety is strangers: 'I don't like dealing with strangers. And then two strangers that change like another level of energy' (09:34). Bryant resolves this anxiety by progressively disclosing personal details about Greg and Johan: Greg is 28, male, works in interior design, from Connecticut. Johan is 34, female, works in banking/Manhattan, from Connecticut, wants to be near her brother. Each detail converts the guests from abstract 'strangers' to concrete people. But this disclosure is conversational and sequential -- it unfolds over time, each new detail building on the last. The platform currently presents guest profiles as static data cards: all information at once, in a structured format. This loses the progressive disclosure power that makes the call effective. Showing everything at once is like meeting someone and immediately learning their full biography -- it's informationally complete but emotionally flat. The reciprocity lens adds another dimension: each piece of guest information Bryant shares is a gift. Sherene reciprocates each gift with a slightly deeper engagement. The platform must preserve this give-and-engage rhythm.
elements.solution: Design guest profiles as a progressive disclosure sequence that mirrors the conversational revelation of personal details. (1) First disclosure (visible before any host action): name, age, gender, and reason for needing the space. This is what Bryant shares first -- enough to create a person, not just a profile. (2) Second disclosure (available after host expresses interest): employment, schedule, duration, and origin location. This mirrors Bryant sharing 'Greg works in interior design' and 'Johan is from Connecticut' after Sherene engages. (3) Third disclosure (available after host requests interview): vetting form results, custom question answers, vaccination status. This is the deepest level, corresponding to Bryant's promise to 'share our vetting form with them.' (4) Each disclosure level should be framed as a gift: 'Here is what we know about Greg' (not 'Greg's profile'). The framing matters -- 'what we know' implies the platform investigated on the host's behalf, which is a gift of effort. (5) Between each disclosure level, include a micro-action from the host (expand the profile, click 'Tell me more', request the vetting form). This creates the reciprocal rhythm: platform gives information, host gives engagement.

evidence.quote: First details: 'Two guests who would be in the same room... one for weekdays and the other for the weekend' (00:50). Later: 'Greg is from Connecticut... interior design' (09:06-09:13). Later: 'Johan is 34... he was 28' (11:47-12:00). Each new detail comes after Sherene engages further. By 12:10, Sherene says 'That works' -- the strangers have become known enough.
evidence.insight: The progressive disclosure follows a stranger-to-person arc: abstract schedule -> name and gender -> age and job -> origin and personality. Each step makes the guests less strange. The platform must replicate this arc, not flatten it into a single data card.

evidence.quote: The obligation to receive reduces our ability to choose whom we wish to be indebted to and puts that power in the hands of others.
evidence.insight: When the platform proactively shares guest details (the uninvited gift), the host feels obligated to engage with those details. If the host had to request the information, the obligation would be weaker. The platform should PUSH guest profiles to the host (like Bryant pushing details in conversation), not wait for the host to PULL them.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the guest's human story (name, age, reason for being here). Secondary: practical details (schedule, duration, employment). Tertiary: verification data (vetting results, custom answers). The human story must always be the first thing the host sees -- it converts strangers to people. Verification data is important but should come after the emotional connection is established.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Three-stage progressive disclosure: Stage 1 (pushed to host without request): name, age, reason, schedule. Stage 2 (revealed on host click/tap): employment, origin, lifestyle details. Stage 3 (revealed after host requests or agrees to interview): full vetting results, custom questions, references. Each stage should take 10-15 seconds to read, with a clear action to advance to the next stage.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Stage 1: maximum 5 data points (name, age, gender, reason, schedule). Stage 2: maximum 5 additional data points. Stage 3: maximum 10 data points (vetting is detailed). Never show more than 10 data points simultaneously. Use expandable sections for Stage 3 detail.
scan_order: Guest name and photo (or avatar placeholder)
One-sentence human summary: 'Greg, 28, works in interior design. Needs a Brooklyn weekday base.'
Schedule: visual day-of-week badges showing when they'd be there
Expand for more: employment detail, origin, custom vetting answers
exclude: Technical identifiers (user IDs, booking references) in the primary scan path.
Negative information in Stage 1 (credit issues, past disputes). This belongs in Stage 3 vetting detail only, if at all.
Generic platform language ('Guest #1 Profile'). Use the guest's actual name from the first pixel.
Any formatting that makes the profile feel like a database record rather than a person. No tables, no grids of key-value pairs in Stage 1.

elements.title: Reciprocity-Anchored Pricing Display: Show What You Get Before What You Pay
elements.problem: Pricing information on the platform is typically displayed as a number: '$40/night' or '$1,200/month.' But Cialdini's contrast principle and reciprocity research show that a number without context is evaluated by whatever anchor the viewer brings. Sherene's anchor is 'barely breaking even' (23:53) -- she sees any price through the lens of whether it covers her costs. Bryant reframes this by first showing what Sherene GETS (two reliable guests, daily payment, relationship management, premium above her asking price) and then naming the price. This gift-before-price framing makes the price feel like a fair exchange rather than a bare number. The platform's pricing UI shows the number first and the value second (or never), which forces the host to evaluate price in a vacuum.
elements.solution: Restructure pricing display to follow the reciprocity-anchored pattern: show what the host receives before showing any dollar amounts. (1) Before any price appears, show the value stack: 'Included with your arrangement: daily payment guarantees, electronic lockbox, photo documentation, cleaning checklists, guest vetting, hosted interviews, security deposit management.' Each item in the stack is a gift that anchors the price. (2) Then show the price with Cialdini's contrast principle applied: show what the host would earn with a single traditional guest first (lower number), then show the ghost roommate premium (higher number). 'Traditional single guest: ~$800/month. Your ghost roommate arrangement: $1,200/month.' The contrast makes the premium feel larger. (3) Show the daily breakdown: '$40/night, paid to you the morning after each stay.' This makes the payment feel immediate and concrete, reinforcing the daily reciprocity cycle. (4) Show the net-of-costs view: 'After your estimated laundry and cleaning costs ($X), your net monthly income is $Y.' Sherene is explicitly worried about breaking even -- address this directly.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'One thing with these ghost roommate situations we see a lot of the time is we're able to provide the host with a better price than what they're asking for. And it looks like this will be the case as well, where we can give you more than a thousand.' Bryant shows the value (better-than-expected price) before naming the number.
evidence.insight: The value proposition precedes the price in the call. The platform must replicate this: never show a price without first showing the value it buys.

evidence.quote: If the second item is fairly different from the first, we will tend to see it as more different than it actually is. So if we lift a light object first and then lift a heavy object, we will estimate the second object to be heavier than if we had lifted it without first trying the light one.
evidence.insight: Show the lower single-guest earning first, then the ghost roommate earning. The contrast makes the premium feel more valuable. This is the clothing store principle applied to pricing display: show the suit ($1200 ghost roommate) after the sweater ($800 single guest), not before.

evidence.quote: Sherene: 'I'm looking at this and I'm just seeing some numbers, the worst had to be $40 a night. I want to just check them on rates in the area because I want to say it was sort of what is like a profitable number. Cause right now it was just barely breaking even.'
evidence.insight: Sherene is doing mental math to determine profitability. The platform must do this math for her and present it visually: revenue minus costs equals profit. The host should never have to calculate profitability in their head.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: what the host receives (value stack of included services). Secondary: comparative pricing (single-guest vs ghost-roommate premium). Tertiary: raw numbers (nightly rate, monthly total, daily payment amount). The dollar sign should never be the first thing the eye hits on a pricing page.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Value-then-price progressive disclosure: First, show the full value stack (3-5 included services, each as a small card or badge). Second, show the comparative earnings (single vs ghost roommate, with visual contrast). Third, show the detailed breakdown (nightly, weekly, monthly, with cost offset). Allow the host to toggle between views without losing the value context.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 numbers visible simultaneously in the primary view. The host should see: monthly total, nightly rate, and one comparison number (single-guest equivalent or net-of-costs). Detailed breakdowns available on expansion. No financial jargon ('amortized rate', 'yield', 'occupancy rate') -- use plain language ('You earn', 'After costs', 'Per night').
scan_order: Value headline: 'Your ghost roommate arrangement includes:' + 3-5 benefit badges
Comparison anchor: 'vs. $800/month with a single guest' (smaller, providing contrast)
Daily detail: '$40/night, paid the morning after each stay' (smallest, supporting)
exclude: Raw percentages ('12% above market rate') without the underlying dollar amounts. Hosts think in dollars, not percentages.
Platform fee information in the primary pricing view. Show net-to-host earnings first. Fee details belong in an expandable section.
Pricing for other hosts or other markets. Show only this host's specific numbers.
Any pricing display that requires the host to perform mental arithmetic. If the host must add, subtract, or multiply, the information architecture has failed.

elements.title: Active Lease Reciprocity Feed: Continuous Balance Visibility
elements.problem: During the active lease, the host needs to see that the reciprocal arrangement is working -- that guests are fulfilling their obligations (cleaning, respectful use, timely schedule adherence) and that the platform is fulfilling its obligations (timely payment, dispute availability, relationship management). Currently, this information is scattered: payments in one view, cleaning records in messages, guest behavior inferred from absence of complaints. There is no unified feed that shows the reciprocity balance at a glance. Cialdini's research shows that visible reciprocity creates social pressure to maintain balance. The ghost roommate model is especially vulnerable because two guests create more reciprocity touchpoints (cleaning handoffs, storage sharing, schedule adherence) than a single guest. If the balance becomes invisible, it becomes unmaintainable.
elements.solution: Create a unified Active Lease Reciprocity Feed that shows all give-receive exchanges in chronological order, visible to the host at all times. (1) Structure the feed as a timeline of reciprocal events: 'Mon AM: Greg checked in. Mon PM: $40 payment released. Wed PM: Greg completed cleaning checklist. Thu AM: Johan checked in. Thu PM: $40 payment released.' Each entry shows who gave what and when. (2) Color-code by reciprocity status: green for completed exchanges (guest stayed + payment released), amber for pending (guest stayed + payment processing), red for broken (cleaning missed, payment failed). (3) Show weekly and monthly summaries at the top: 'This week: 6/6 nights occupied, $240 earned, 2/2 cleaning handoffs completed.' (4) Include guest-to-guest reciprocity: 'Greg completed cleaning before Johan's arrival' and 'Johan left storage area tidy before Greg's return.' This makes the three-way reciprocity web visible. (5) At renewal time, show the cumulative feed: 'Over 3 months: 78 nights hosted, $3,120 earned, 24 cleaning handoffs completed, 0 incidents.' This cumulative gift is the most powerful retention argument.

evidence.quote: Bryant describes photo documentation for storage ('having pictures and basically records of what's being stored') and cleaning checklists ('we can start with a checklist and make sure that things are being held accountable'). Both are reciprocity-tracking mechanisms that Bryant instinctively knows are needed.
evidence.insight: Bryant's instinct to create records (photos, checklists) is the analog precursor to a digital reciprocity feed. The platform must formalize these records into a continuous, visible timeline that the host can check at any time.

evidence.quote: Because there is general distaste for those who take and make no effort to give in return, we will often go to great lengths to avoid being considered one of their number. It is to those lengths that we will often be taken and, in the process, be 'taken' by individuals who stand to gain from our indebtedness.
evidence.insight: Visible records of reciprocal exchange create social pressure on all parties to maintain balance. If Greg can see (through the app) that Johan always completes the cleaning checklist, Greg will feel social pressure to do the same. The feed is not surveillance -- it is reciprocity reinforcement through visibility.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current reciprocity status (is everything balanced right now?). Secondary: recent exchange history (last 7 days of give-receive events). Tertiary: cumulative summary (total earnings, total handoffs, incident history). The host should be able to answer 'Is everything okay?' in under 3 seconds from the primary view.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Dashboard-first, timeline-on-demand: Show the summary dashboard (all green / some amber / any red) as the primary view. Allow the host to drill into the chronological timeline for detail. Show weekly summaries automatically every Monday. Show monthly summaries on the 1st of each month. Show the cumulative summary at renewal time.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Dashboard summary: maximum 4 status indicators (payments, cleaning, schedule, storage). Timeline: maximum 10 entries visible at once, with scroll for more. Weekly summary: maximum 6 data points. The host must never need to read more than 30 seconds of feed to understand the current reciprocity status.
scan_order: Status indicator: green/amber/red for overall reciprocity health
Key metric: 'This week: $X earned, Y/Z handoffs completed'
Action needed (if any): 'Johan's cleaning checklist is pending confirmation'
exclude: Raw data without interpretation. Don't show '6 events this week' -- show '6/6 exchanges completed successfully.'
Guest-to-guest private interactions. The host sees the reciprocity balance that affects them, not private messages between guests.
Historical data older than the current lease period in the primary view. Older data belongs in an archive accessible on demand.
Negative framing for positive outcomes. Don't show '0 incidents' -- show 'Clean track record' or 'All handoffs successful.'
